info.game_comments: Ten April Fools' Easter eggs edited into the show.

double_jeopardy_round: ON THE OLD MAP OF EUROPE

(1, 1).clue: (David Muir, anchor of ABC's World News Tonight, presents.)  In 2015, I helped moderate the third Democratic presidential debate & asked the candidates about topics including whether to accept refugees from this specific country

(2, 1).clue: One who admires the customs of England

(3, 1).clue: In a classic '70s sitcom, newsroommates Gavin MacLeod, Edward Asner & Ted Knight

(4, 1).clue: To see how this religious sect lives in Lancaster, Penn., you can take a buggy ride in the country & visit one of their farms

(5, 1).clue: Wagner tubas were built especially for this 4-opera cycle

(6, 1).clue: You can whiten your smile with this brand's 3D White toothpaste & Whitestrips

(1, 2).clue: (David Muir presents.)  In my 2015 interview with Hillary Clinton, she said, quote "That was a mistake, I'm sorry" about using one of these while Secretary of State

(3, 2).clue: Tim Daly & Tea Leoni, dealing with the federal government

(4, 2).clue: Every June & July, "The Miracle Worker" is performed on the grounds of Ivy Green, her home in Tuscumbia

(5, 2).clue: This character seen here is both musical & instrumental

(6, 2).clue: You might want to use a toothpaste that controls this, hardened plaque

(1, 3).clue: (David Muir presents.)  Marking an abrupt change after decades, the normalization of relations with this country was the subject of an exclusive interview I conducted with President Obama in December of 2014

(3, 3).clue: Abbi Jacobson & Ilana Glazer, navigating New York

(4, 3).clue: Louisburg Square in this "elevated" neighborhood of Boston features red brick townhomes & a gated private park

(5, 3).clue: In the 1890s this "March King" redeveloped a style of bass tuba that was eventually named for him

(1, 4).clue: (David Muir presents.)  Political reporting often means hitting the presidential campaign trail, like I did in 2015 when I conducted a one-on-one interview in English & Spanish with this ex-governor

(2, 4).clue: One who enjoys wines as a connoisseur

(3, 4).clue: Jim Caviezel & Michael Emerson, fighting evil in a high-tech way

(4, 4).clue: You can visit a weather museum at the top of this New Hampshire peak, reachable via a cog railway

(5, 4).clue: The name of this instrument, which serves as a tenor tuba in military bands, is from the Greek for "good sounding"

(1, 5).clue: (David Muir presents.)  I interviewed this first-term senator in April 2014 & she insisted she was not running for president

(2, 5).clue: A lover of words; hopefully you're enough of one to get this

(3, 5).clue: Noah Wyle & Moon Bloodgood began dealing with aliens in 2011

(4, 5).clue: The National Farm Toy Museum in Dyersville is an attraction in this corn-rich state

(5, 5).clue: His album "Birth of the Cool" includes the French horn & tuba, instruments rarely heard in a jazz context

(1, 1).clue: Colombian writer Jose Eustasio Rivera's 1924 novel "The Vortex" was set in the rubber plantations of this rain forest

(2, 1).clue: The Carrara quarries in Tuscany are prized for this rock used by Michelangelo for his "Pieta"

(3, 1).clue: Profession that made Oscar de la Renta famous

(4, 1).clue: A baby is a small one of these, usually about 750 watts

(5, 1).clue: Two countries visible on the map of Europe today used to be united as this dual monarchy

(6, 1).clue: This 6-letter term is used to describe the climbing of a mountain

(1, 2).clue: Mexican poet Octavio Paz quit his diplomatic post due to a massacre of protesters 10 days before this 1968 event

(2, 2).clue: Sial, the upper layer of the Earth's crust, primarily consists of these 2 elements

(3, 2).clue: This "Big O" was only the second NBAer to score more than 25,000 points

(4, 2).clue: A delight to most actors, "S.R.O." stands for this, meaning a packed house

(5, 2).clue: On Oct. 7, 1949 the Soviets announced the formation of this country, aka the DDR

(6, 2).clue: A position on an issue, or a batting position at home plate

(1, 3).clue: Gauchesco is literature about the South American equivalent of this American job

(2, 3).clue: The inside walls of these hollow rocks are lined with crystals

(3, 3).clue: Author Oscar Hijuelos created this group who "Play Songs of Love"

(4, 3).clue: It means to furnish a stage with props, scenery & furniture, but not necessarily clothing

(5, 3).clue: Caesar could tell you France & parts of other nations made up this region that faded from history in the 500s

(6, 3).clue: A Hindu social division with its own privileges & restrictions

(1, 4).clue: His 1985 work "Love in the Time of Cholera" was partially based on his parents' courtship

(3, 4).clue: This member of the double-first-name club has played Llewyn Davis & Poe Dameron

(4, 4).clue: A rumble pot is a receptacle in which hot water is mixed with this, solid carbon dioxide, to create fog

(5, 4).clue: In 1946 this federal state took up a big slab of the Balkans with 6 republics; in 2003, not so much

(1, 5).clue: This writer who died fighting for Cuba's independence in 1895 is a national hero of the island

(2, 5).clue: A prized variety of this ornamental stone mined in the American Southwest is robin's egg blue

(3, 5).clue: "A Jazz Odyssey" is the autobiography of this pianist

(4, 5).clue: This 2-word term for sound effects from out of view of the audience is also the name of a 1982 play by Michael Frayn

(5, 5).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew shows a map on the monitor.)  A big player in Medieval & Renaissance times, by 1861, the entity known as these "States" shrank to a dot on the map

(0, 0).clue: Of Asia's 10 most populous urban areas, this city on an island is the only one south of the equator
